We appreciated the fact that they were timely, our reservation was set for 7:15 pm and we were outside seated by 7:25 pm. We sat outside in the middle of October and it was not cold, they had heaters set up all around.
Our favorite dish was the truffle honey whipped ricotta, incredible! Order their free focaccia bread basket and it goes great with it. Food was good, not excellent but the ambience and the service made up for it. Wonderful date spot / somewhere to celebrate a special occasion! Recommending coming after sunset go get a beautiful view of the bridge.
reviews.author: Erica Matos

results.name: Gran Electrica
results.summary: Come for the margaritas, stay for the Baja-style fish tacos ‚Äî this place nails the festive vibe, especially on the back patio strung with lights. The barbacoa, slow-cooked until it falls apart, is a definite highlight for sharing with a group.

personalization.forUser: Okay, you'll love this spot for a big group, especially if everyone's down for amazing Mexican street food and strong margaritas. Plus, it's not Thai, but the vibrant flavors might just scratch that itch for bold tastes like you get with Thai food.

reviews.text: The place has an incredible patio which provides a great time to enjoy food. We ordered the elote, guacamole and chips, ceviche,  chicken quesadillas and the cochinita pibil. The elote came with aioli, but a Mexican cream would had provided more acidity and flavor to it. The oyster were very good. The quesadilla con chilorio de pollo was flavorful, but the tortilla was chewy. The same case  of thick and chewy tortillas came with the pibil. The pibil was nicely seasoned and cooked. The ceviche had a nice ‚ÄúTigre de leche‚Äù but very little fish. There was plenty of mango and jicama. The margaritas were very good as it was for the service.
reviews.author: William H. Lemos

reviews.text: We just searched for Spanish Mexican restaurant in Dumbo area  after long day to sightseeing the city. We decided to stop here for food. The first step we walked here we love the decoration and the atmosphere it‚Äôs modern and clean. We got offered to sit at the back garden which is really nice and comfy. We ordered chips with salsa which different from another place we had. Taco is  good and grilled cheese stuff inside the chili that i couldn‚Äôt remember. All it‚Äôs good. The staff are nice. Overall is good to try in dumbo area.
reviews.author: Wit Tara

reviews.text:
I can't speak to the food since we just popped in for a night cap, but the cocktails were excellent. The ambiance was great (very dim lit romantic type of setting). If you're in the area and looking for some tasty, but unique cocktails, I'd definitely recommend it. The service was solid as well.

Drinks: 5/5
Price: 4.5/5
Ambiance: 4.5/5

Overall: 4.8/5
reviews.author: Khalid

results.name: DeStefano's Steakhouse
results.summary: Come for the porterhouse, stay for the old-school Brooklyn vibe ‚Äî it's like stepping into a Scorsese film. The service is impeccable, and they know how to treat a large group, making it a reliable choice for a celebratory dinner.

personalization.forUser: You'll love this place for a big group ‚Äì the portions are huge, perfect for sharing family-style, and it's loud enough that you can all actually hear each other. It's not Thai, but sometimes you need a break from your favorite cuisines!

reviews.text:
I took my mom to this restaurant again for her birthday. The new location is not far from the old location and the decorations of the place are the same. Menu also the same or pretty close to last time my mom was here too. Steak is always great and I love bacon so much.

My family enjoy so much and I'm happy that I take her out to her favorite restaurant.
reviews.author: Melissa Naja

reviews.text:
We went to have steaks. They did not disappoint. The ribeye and filet mugnon were cooked to order, flavorful, and good size. The appetizers are tasty and good size for sharing. They have a large wine selection.
It can get loud even if its half full.
reviews.author: Yuliya Akchurina

reviews.text: Famous steakhouse nearby was cash only and ATM charges us 25%. So decided to challenge DeStefano‚Äôs found on google map. We liked it and highly recommended. Not sure when I will be around next time but definitely coming back here.
reviews.author: Shuhei Takeda

results.name: Brooklyn Crab
results.summary: Okay, the crab legs are solid, but you're *really* here for the sprawling outdoor deck with its ridiculous mini-golf course. It's pure, unadulterated summertime chaos, perfect for a big group that doesn't take itself too seriously.

personalization.forUser: Okay, so it's not Thai or Ethiopian, but picture this: you're with a big group, sunshine, and platters of seafood. Plus, the lively atmosphere might just have some echoes of that world music vibe you dig ‚Äì skip it if you're looking for a quiet night, though.

reviews.text:
Brooklyn Crab in Red Hook is nothing short of a gem. From the moment you step in, you're greeted by an atmosphere that perfectly blends rustic charm with vibrant coastal vibes. The decor is stunning both inside and out, featuring nautical elements that create a relaxed yet energetic ambiance. It's the kind of place you can enjoy for a casual lunch or a special evening out.

Now, let‚Äôs talk about the food‚Äîit's simply amazing! The seafood is incredibly fresh, and you can taste the quality in every bite. I highly recommend the crab dishes; they are cooked to perfection and bursting with flavor. The menu offers a variety of options, ensuring there's something for everyone. Pair your meal with one of their creative cocktails or a cold beer, and you're in for a treat.

The service at Brooklyn Crab truly stands out. Michael and Zay were exceptional, providing attentive and friendly service that made our dining experience even more enjoyable. They were knowledgeable about the menu and offered great recommendations, ensuring we had everything we needed without feeling rushed.

Every aspect of our visit was fantastic, from the stunning views of the waterfront to the delicious food and impeccable service. I loved everything about this place, and I can't wait to return. Whether you're a local or just visiting, Brooklyn Crab is a must-visit destination that will leave you craving more!
reviews.author: Vikki Smallz

reviews.text: This place was a date night for my husband and I.  I mainly stick to a pescatarian diet. The food was amazing. I loved it. It was roughly an hour and a half before they closed. The young guy there really had the bar managed while grabbing food for the customers. He gave fantastic customer service. I sure will be coming back. I recommend this place to anyone looking for good seafood. I think my husband and I found our new spot to eat! ü§©
reviews.author: Miss Dae

reviews.text: Definitely a vibes spot, with great views of the waterfront which make for a memorable sunset shot. Oysters are decent, and the lobster roll does the job although I‚Äôve had better for sure. Good offering of cocktails and wines as well.
reviews.author: Rovik Robert

results.name: Tacocina
results.summary: The al pastor here is the real deal, carved right off the trompo ‚Äî the outdoor setting is perfect for a casual group hang, especially with a round of margaritas.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for **Thai** and **Ethiopian**, the bold flavors here might be too simple for you, Jordan. It's a fun spot, but maybe not the complex culinary adventure you're craving.

reviews.text:
I‚Äôve been coming here for years for a quick bite before a show at BAM across the street but I realized last night it was also convenient if you‚Äôre going to Brooklyn Paramount that‚Äôs also around the corner.

The food is always on point, the service is quick and the tacos are muy delicioso (pardon my Spanish). I always get the crispy fish tacos which are perfectly fried and battered, a michelada with Modelo and the fresh made guacamole but you can‚Äôt go wrong with anything on the menu.

Get a reservation though because they are known to book up when there‚Äôs a show going on!
reviews.author: Stinson Parks III

reviews.text:
Tacombi in downtown Brooklyn is one of those spots that immediately draws you in with its vibrant atmosphere and inviting setting. The d√©cor has a fun, casual vibe with a distinctly Mexican flair, making it an enjoyable place to sit back and share a meal with friends. Its location is also a big plus‚Äîeasily accessible and surrounded by the lively energy that makes Brooklyn dining such a great experience. On the service side, the staff is attentive and welcoming, which definitely adds to the overall positive impression.

That said, when it comes to the food itself, there‚Äôs room for improvement. The portions are fair for the price, which I do appreciate. It doesn‚Äôt feel like you‚Äôre being shorted, and value-wise it lines up with what you‚Äôd expect in the area. However, the flavors don‚Äôt quite deliver on the same level as the atmosphere and service. While the tacos and other dishes look appealing and are plated nicely, the taste can feel a little underwhelming‚Äîmissing some of the depth and punch you might anticipate from authentic Mexican street-style food. Nothing was terrible, but nothing stood out enough to make me crave coming back solely for the food.

Another point worth mentioning is the drink selection. Tacombi only offers Lupita sodas, which feels limiting. While Lupita may be their in-house brand, it almost comes across as being pushed onto customers since there aren‚Äôt other soda options available. If you‚Äôre not a fan of Lupita‚Äôs particular flavor profile, that leaves you with little choice, which takes away from the overall dining flexibility.

All in all, Tacombi has great potential. With its charming setting, convenient location, and solid service, it sets high expectations. If the food‚Äôs flavors were elevated to match the rest of the experience, it could easily become a go-to spot. For now, it sits at a solid three stars.
reviews.author: Joga gavidia

reviews.text: My girlfriend and I decided to come here last minute for our 4-year anniversary, and I‚Äôm so glad we did! I was a little skeptical at first, but the food completely blew me away. The chicken, shrimp, and birria tacos were fresh and packed with flavor, and the drinks were amazing too. Service was excellent‚Äîour waiter was professional, attentive, and made the night feel special. Highly recommend Tacombi Fort Greene for delicious food and great vibes!
reviews.author: Edwin M.

results.name: Randolph's Bar
results.summary: Randolph's is a solid neighborhood bar that's surprisingly roomy, making it a decent spot for a low-key group hangout. The real draw? A surprisingly good burger that soaks up the beer nicely; it's the kind of place where you can actually hear each other talk.

personalization.forUser: This place is more about the beer and the boisterous crowd than any culinary adventure, so skip it unless you're just looking for a pre-dinner drink; it definitely won't scratch that itch for Thai.

reviews.text: This is a very chill spot with some of the best mix drinks I had recently. The mojito is definitely worth checking out. The menu offers typical dishes you would see at most establishments similar in nature, however they were very well prepared and made. Overall, the spot has a mixed crowd (young/old) and the staff is very friendly. This is a spot worth checking out if you are in the area and just need to hang out and enjoy the drinks.
reviews.author: Konrad Strumidlo

reviews.text: The Randolph is a dope spot to chill and hang out, I like the games and different couches to lounge around. And I really like their food, it's typical bar style food, but everything I've had so far has been slammin
reviews.author: Alexx Smith

reviews.text:
Super underrated BK brewery. Great brew options the cover the full gambit of beer types + solid cocktails & a full bar. Food was great too. Chopped cheese sliders are A1.

Used to pass this place all the time thinking it was a small bar/brewery but it had a great standard bar with nice seating, a great pretty fun arcade and a gorgeous rooftop that has some of the best views the city has to offer. I‚Äôm talking midtown + Statue of Liberty! Definitely worth pullin up.
reviews.author: Vitthal

results.name: Pig Beach BBQ
results.summary: Forget dainty; Pig Beach is a full-on BBQ experience, perfect for a crowd that's serious about smoked meat. Their spare ribs, with that perfect bark and tender pull, are the star, and the lively outdoor space feels like a backyard party, even if your backyard doesn't have a smoker the size of a small car.

personalization.forUser: Okay, so Pig Beach isn't exactly Thai or Ethiopian, but the communal tables and lively atmosphere are perfect for a big group, and the brisket is killer. You'll love the bluesy vibe, even if it's not your usual jazz scene.

reviews.text:
The front of the restaurant now has umbrellas, high chairs and tables. The back has low benches with umbrellas to help with the sun. As soon as you enter they ask of you can stay for maximum 90 minutes. It was spacious packed in my 90 minutes. Food was quickly made, and good. Not a big fan of non baked mac and cheese. Drinks were good. The ready made cocktails were watered down.
Great experience and service.
reviews.author: Kafi Hass

reviews.text: Went middle of a Sunday and surprisingly not full. Food was flavorful and not insanely priced. Brisket and Pork shoulder is great, collard greens are a highlight of the sides. Cocktails expensive but tasty.
reviews.author: Jorge Soto

reviews.text: Hands down, some of the best BBQ, food, and outdoor space in the city. Must order items here are their award winning burger (get the double) and outstanding hatch vinegar wings - and don't forget a side of their pickles to cool you down. They also do fantastic regular BBQ with their brisket, pulled pork, smoked turkey, and other options. The space is massive out back (and inside during normal times) and offers socially distanced seating for guests - and it's a great place to watch a game (again, during normal times). All in all, great food and a place that's run by a great group - highly recommended.
reviews.author: Jeremy McCurdy

turns.message: We want somewhere with good vegetarian options too

turns.query: restaurants good for large groups with vegetarian options in Brooklyn

results.name: al di la Trattoria
results.summary: Al di la's handmade pasta is the real deal, especially the tagliatelle with rabbit ragu ‚Äì incredibly rich and flavorful. The cozy, rustic atmosphere makes it feel like you've stumbled into a hidden gem in Venice, and it's surprisingly accommodating for larger parties if you call ahead.

personalization.forUser: You'll love this for a group dinner ‚Äì it‚Äôs cozy, the pasta is incredible, and they always have some amazing vegetarian options, just be sure to book ahead. It‚Äôs not Thai, but it‚Äôs comforting and delicious!

reviews.text: Excellent service and great food! The Pappardelle Al Funghi was comforting and full of flavor, while the Ribeye with mashed potatoes and truffle shavings was cooked perfectly. Would absolutely recommend to friends.
reviews.author: Elana Mendoza

reviews.text: From the moment we arrived we felt like family. The service was excellent! My husband and I went for a quick bite after work. The food was so delicious and fresh. The waiter recommended the Fisherman‚Äôs stew. Each bite was like a burst of the ocean with all the Italian spices. The seafood was fresh and so delicate!!! Thank you Chef for an amazing meal!!!
reviews.author: Mona Tramonte

reviews.text: If you would like to have a terrific time dining, this is the place for you and your guests. Excellent food, fantastic service and an ambiance to boot. Thank you ... we will sure be coming back.
reviews.author: KMN

results.name: Lilia
results.summary: The mafaldine with pink peppercorn is worth the trip alone ‚Äî Lilia's buzzing energy on weekend nights makes it a blast for groups, though you'll want to book *very* early. The grilled clams are another must-order, perfect for sharing.

personalization.forUser: Okay, Lilia is HUGE and always packed, so wrangling a big group will be tough, but if you can swing it? The handmade pasta, especially the cacio e pepe, is worth the hassle, even if it's not exactly resonating with your love for Thai.

reviews.text: This place is simply phenomenal. I went for the first time over a year ago, and have been dreaming about their proscuitto di parma (aged 24 months and then placed on a tomato crustini) ever since. I went back yesterday, and it was just as good. I can‚Äôt express enough how amazing this place is, and the service was wonderful. All the servers are friendly and helpful, and were willing to accommodate our quick turn-around time of 30 minutes on a busy weekend. I‚Äôve tried a ton of italian food in NYC, and this place is hands down my favorite. The pasta is handmade and the desserts & drinks are also excellent. I honestly don‚Äôt have a bad thing to say about it - we went back two days in a row because the proscuitto bruschetta was so amazing. THANK YOU TO ALL THE STAFF AND CHEFS AT AURORA.
reviews.author: Violet E

reviews.text:
This place is a gem! Rustic and cozy.

Wonderful ambiance and excellent service by Antonio, our server, and CJ, the manager, who welcomed us like family. We truly felt like we were home, which was nice because we were celebrating a pre-wedding family dinner.

The food was wonderful and delicious. We started with a few appetizers to share and most of us  got pasta entr√©es but some also ordered the steak, the pork, and risotto with wine overflowing to multiple toasts of course! We finished with an array of desserts that was a perfect finish to a perfect meal.
reviews.author: Beckmoi

reviews.text: Although I'm giving it 4 stars, I do believe if I go back, I'll change it to 5. The food was good, the atmosphere was great, and the service was ok. In their defense, they were getting ready for a wedding that was happening 1 and a half hours after our reservation. We had the bunch menu and it had a good variety of options. We had, duck sausage, pasta, french toast, and a burger. The total came out to about 100 dollars. This was a very fair price considering it was for 2 people and we over ordered.
reviews.author: Adi Avishalom

results.name: Roberta's Pizza
results.summary: Roberta's backyard is a total scene, especially on a summer night, and the wood-fired pizzas are consistently incredible‚Äîget the Bee Sting for the perfect sweet-and-spicy kick. Surprisingly, their house-made bread is almost as craveable as the pizza.

personalization.forUser: Okay, so it's pizza, but the veggie options are legit and they totally nail the group vibe. Plus, they often spin jazz records, so you'll dig the tunes while you're crushing some pies.

reviews.text: 5/5 stars! Found this as a new toogoodtogo spot as of Jan 2026 & the owner was very kind, service was fast, felt bad bc I came 5min before closing and they were wonderful and the food tastes great! Fast packaging and fresh food traveling in the snow & they taped up the boxes and gave me 4 extra slices because they were closing the store for the night, so I really appreciate it!
reviews.author: Eunji Kim

reviews.text:
First time here and I would be coming back . I ordered 2 slices to-go ; a Cajun chicken & Caesar slice.

I‚Äôm a fan of the thin crust (extra crunch ) üçï‚ù§Ô∏è

Workers are nice üëçüèΩ
reviews.author: abigail m

reviews.text: The pizza are pretty good. Ordered the cheeseburger deluxe today, the fries were the only thing that needs a redo. They were very soggy and oily! My guess is that the oil they cooked them is warm not hot! They need to address this! Soggy fries are the worse!
reviews.author: luis lerebours

results.name: Gran Electrica
results.summary: I'm obsessed with their cauliflower tacos ‚Äì smoky, spicy, and surprisingly filling. The string lights and outdoor seating create a festive vibe that's perfect for a big group looking for a lively night.

personalization.forUser: Since you enjoy Thai food, the vibrant flavors of their Mexican dishes might be a fun detour, plus they've got vegetarian options for the whole crew. However, it can get pretty loud, so maybe not the spot for deep conversations over jazz.

reviews.text: If you‚Äôve been around Dumbo before, you know that restaurants will charge an arm and a leg for the same dish half the price elsewhere. Not the case here! The food here was really authentic and flavorful, the walls were just covered with notes from visitors all over the world, and the service was incredibly fast considering there were about 2 servers and maybe one guy in the kitchen. The atmosphere is also festive all year round‚Äîjust a cool taco joint overall! Glad I stumbled in and discovered this gem of restaurant! Highly recommend!
reviews.author: Jimmy Liang

reviews.text:
I really wanted to like Pedro‚Äôs. The space itself is cute and well-located, and the food was okay‚Äîbut nothing memorable. It could really benefit from more of an authentic Mexican vibe, both in atmosphere and flavor.

Service was just average. Even though we were the only people there, we had to call the waitress three separate times to get attention.

The biggest downside, unfortunately, was the smell. Throughout our time sitting there, there was a strong backed-up sewage odor that came and went. It was noticeable enough to affect the experience, and it seemed like the restaurant was trying to mask it with a mister rather than fixing the root issue. When I politely mentioned it to the waitress, she dismissed it as if I was imagining things instead of acknowledging the concern.

To the owner: the sewer issue really needs to be addressed. It overshadows everything else and makes it hard to enjoy what could otherwise be a nice spot.
reviews.author: Orelvis Pizano

reviews.text:
Honestly, this place is a hidden gem! A Mexican restaurant with the most beautiful touch: amazing Venezuelan people running it with so much love and kindness. From the moment you walk in, you feel like family.

I have to highlight Valentina!! her energy is absolutely radiant. She‚Äôs beyond attentive, sweet, and makes you feel at home instantly. She doesn‚Äôt just serve food, she serves joy. People like her make the whole experience unforgettable.

The food? Delicious. The vibe? Warm. The service? Impeccable. I can‚Äôt recommend this spot enough it‚Äôs the kind of place you‚Äôll want to come back to over and over again.

If you‚Äôre looking for a restaurant with incredible flavors and even better people, this is it. Full recommendation from me! üíØ

They made my birthday a whole celebration!!
reviews.author: Ray Mendez

results.name: Colonia Verde
results.summary: The backyard garden at Colonia Verde is an absolute oasis, making it a dreamy spot for a group dinner. Don't miss the grilled cauliflower tacos with cashew crema ‚Äî even committed carnivores will be impressed.

personalization.forUser: Okay, this spot has a beautiful garden setting that could be amazing for a big group, and they definitely have vegetarian options. However, I'm not sure if the modern Latin vibe will quite scratch that itch for, say, Ethiopian food.

reviews.text: Very good place for Latin flavors in neighborhood. I really enjoyed the La Picosa drink: the cucumber & lime flavor really stood out (very refreshing and presentation was nice). The breakfast tacos tasted very healthy and all the duck dishes were well executed. Cute space in the backyard but only for rsvp folks ‚Äî we were walk-in so seated at bar (I recommend taking rsvp in advance). Service was good and overall good vibes.
reviews.author: Amandip Kaur

reviews.text:
Phenomenal atmosphere and food.  If you can, book the garden area in the back.  It will be easier to snag at the 6pm timing than the 7pm.  It will enhance your experience 2 fold.

Dishes to try:
- Trout Ceviche
- Fried Pork Belly
- Shrimp Tacos

About the only downside is that cocktails were a little strong, which is not relevant for everyone, and seen as a bonus to others.
reviews.author: James Mullin

reviews.text: Overall food is more hits but some misses. I really liked the mushroom taco and shrimp that came out sizzling in flavorful garlic butter. These were the most tasty dishes. I also loved their arepa and cheesy bread - the texture was amazing! Other dishes like the mac and cheese, duck taco, steak were so so.
reviews.author: Isabelle J

results.name: Miss Ada
results.summary: Miss Ada nails modern Israeli cuisine, and their creamy hummus with perfectly charred pita is a must-order for the table. The backyard garden strung with lights creates a magical, intimate vibe that's surprisingly great for larger groups looking for something special.

personalization.forUser: Since you love Thai food, you'll appreciate the similar vibrant and fresh flavors in Miss Ada‚Äôs Israeli dishes, especially the grilled halloumi and the flavorful salads‚Äîperfect for a group with vegetarian friends.

reviews.text:
I honestly wish I could give the service a 6/5, but I will make do with what I got! My fiance and I came here on NYE to do the pre-set menu of house favorites. The place was decorated so cute and they had little party favors everywhere for NYE. When we arrived, we got seated at the bar even though we made a reservation at the back patio on Resy. When I let the manager know, she was so apologetic about the Resy app incorrectly placing guests into the wrong areas of the restaurant and asked us if she could purchase our first round of drinks to make up for it. No problem! So we are eating dinner at the bar and she kept coming up to us after we were done with the cocktails offering us wine, refills, and even a great dessert wine that the bartender recommended with the babka. When I tell you this is some of the best food AND service i‚Äôve ever experienced- what an incredible way to end 2025!!! At the end we expected to pay for the drinks completely and were told they were all on the house. Shocked and on cloud 9, beyond full, we left the restaurant so happy and a little tipsy.

As for the food, obsessed with the hummus and ricotta cheese, as well as the kofta was the best I‚Äôve ever had. Babka was amazing and everything else was so yummy, my fiance never had Israeli food before and was cautiously optimistic going into the dinner I chose, and left saying that was his favorite meal from our NYC trip! Thank you so much to the team of Miss Ada!! highly highly recommend!!!!
reviews.author: Hannah

reviews.text: Cute and cozy vibe. Food was delicious, the fish was super tender. Good selection of wines and friendly service. Great example of what to expect in the fort Greene neighborhood. Verdict: will return and recommend!
reviews.author: Patrick K

reviews.text: Celebrated my husband's birthday and had the most wonderful experience!! Every single bite of food was absolutely delicious. We especially loved the short rib hummus, halloumi skewers, falafel, and pita bread üòä Super friendly and sweet staff as well. They even surprised us at the end with a little cup of gelato with a candle in it. This was our 4th time dining at Miss Ada and we will definitely continue to come back!! üß°üß°üß°
reviews.author: Sydney Barton

results.name: Buttermilk Channel
results.summary: Don't let the name fool you; this place is way more than just fried chicken (though the buttermilk fried chicken *is* incredible). The cozy, slightly upscale vibe makes it a solid choice for a group dinner where everyone wants something a little special, and their veggie burger is surprisingly good.

personalization.forUser: Since you enjoy Thai cuisine, the expansive menu here might not be exactly your speed, but they *do* handle larger groups well, and there are a few vegetarian options to keep everyone happy.

results.name: DeStefano's Steakhouse
results.summary: Picture this: exposed brick, the aroma of sizzling steak, and a massive table ready for your crew. Their porterhouse is legendary, and while it's a steakhouse, even vegetarians will find something to love with their hearty sides and pasta dishes.

personalization.forUser: While they can handle a big group and likely have a token veggie option, this is a steakhouse through and through; the focus isn't on vegetarian fare, and it definitely won't scratch that itch for Thai food you love.

reviews.text:
This place has such a unique vibe, I absolutely loved it. Came here for a steak night with a couple friends and we had a phenomenal time. We started with the steak tartare, and avocado & citrus appetizers and followed it up with butcher steaks, which were phenomenal, spinach gratin, mashed potatoes, and finished with the toffee cake. The service was exceptional as well and set a relaxed, fun tone for the entire night.

If you‚Äôre looking for a high quality, unstuffy steak night, you‚Äôre looking for St Anselm.
reviews.author: Rohin Gupta

reviews.text: Amazing culinary experience! The steak was incredibly delicious, and the sides were perfect. Service was excellent too! We walked in and was not able to get a table, but sitting at the bar was intimate and enjoyable nonetheless. Will definitely recommend 10/10.
reviews.author: Kurina Joseph

reviews.text:
This rustic, cozy restaurant presents a good atmosphere for a date night. The menu was simple with different cuts of meat and some seafood options. The butchers steak (price $34) was perfect medium rare and decently flavorful on its own but the portion size was underwhelming for me.

The king Salmon steak tasted good and the portion size was surprisingly large (a good thing in my opinion for the price $42). The sides were decent and the portion size is plenty for 1-2.

Overall the service was decent, food took a little long to come out but it was worth the wait. Parking is limited to the street, I would recommend taking an Uber/Lyft or public transportation here. Don't expect to get a table walking in due to the limited seating.
reviews.author: Ray

results.name: Fausto
results.summary: The handmade pasta at Fausto is seriously impressive, especially the ricotta ravioli with brown butter sage sauce ‚Äî it's a cozy spot that feels surprisingly intimate despite the high ceilings, making it a solid choice for a slightly more sophisticated group outing.

personalization.forUser: Okay, so it's Italian, not **Thai**, but trust me: the handmade pasta here is incredible, perfect for a big group, and they've got some knockout vegetarian options. Plus, the vibe is lively without being deafening ‚Äì you'll love it.

reviews.text: Excellent service and great food! The Pappardelle Al Funghi was comforting and full of flavor, while the Ribeye with mashed potatoes and truffle shavings was cooked perfectly. Would absolutely recommend to friends.
reviews.author: Elana Mendoza

reviews.text: From the moment we arrived we felt like family. The service was excellent! My husband and I went for a quick bite after work. The food was so delicious and fresh. The waiter recommended the Fisherman‚Äôs stew. Each bite was like a burst of the ocean with all the Italian spices. The seafood was fresh and so delicate!!! Thank you Chef for an amazing meal!!!
reviews.author: Mona Tramonte

reviews.text: If you would like to have a terrific time dining, this is the place for you and your guests. Excellent food, fantastic service and an ambiance to boot. Thank you ... we will sure be coming back.
reviews.author: KMN

results.name: Rosemary's
results.summary: Rosemary's focaccia is baked fresh hourly, and the aroma alone is enough to pull you in. The long, family-style tables practically demand you share everything, making it ideal for a boisterous group.

personalization.forUser: Okay, so Rosemary's is Italian, not **Thai**, but hear me out: the family-style platters are perfect for a big group, and their vegetarian options are surprisingly inventive, plus the vibe is buzzing but not deafening, so you'll actually hear each other talk.

reviews.text:
This cute little Italian restaurant is pretty awesome in a quiet little neighborhood. The staff was super nice and made the vibe feel like a chill place to hangout and enjoy your meal.

I got the cacio e pepe which was great. The fresh cracked pepper and the pasta was very fresh and more al dente the way I liked it. This place takes cash only so make sure you have some on you to pay.
reviews.author: Jimmy Si

reviews.text: This intimate gem of a local Italian restaurant is üëåüëåüëå every dish we got were amazing. The pasta was delish, so were the salad, artichokes, and tiramisu. Super kind Italian owner and service
reviews.author: Amy Wu

reviews.text:
Cash only and a small place - there‚Äôs only 5 tables inside. One of the most genuine Italian restaurants I‚Äôve been to. They perfectly prepared the clams so they didn‚Äôt have sand in them which is pretty hard to do. Everything was great. Got hot chocolate to go. Seems like they make a lot of things from scratch.

Update: I come here all the time still and my favorite thing to order is the spaghetti and meatballs. The tiramisu is really good too. They offer sparkling water at a really cheap cost.
reviews.author: Emily

turns.query: best documentaries about music

results.name: Amy
results.summary: Amy Winehouse's raw talent explodes off the screen, but be warned, this isn't a celebration ‚Äî it's a heartbreaking, intimate look at her struggles with addiction, with home video footage that feels almost invasive. The way they use her lyrics as narration is particularly devastating, turning her songs into a kind of tragic prophecy.

personalization.forUser: You dig jazz, and this dives deep into Amy Winehouse's influences, especially the jazz singers she idolized ‚Äì you'll love seeing that connection. Plus, it's a documentary, hitting one of your favorite movie genres.

movies.overview: A pair of ex-lovers spend a spontaneous afternoon together that could either lead to rekindled love or further heartbreak.

results.name: Searching for Sugar Man
results.summary: The twists in this documentary are unreal ‚Äì it feels like a fairy tale, but it's all true. The fact that Rodriguez, the forgotten musician, had no idea he was a superstar in South Africa is mind-blowing, and makes the ending all the more powerful.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for "world" music and indie documentaries, you'll be hooked by this story of a forgotten musician's rediscovery ‚Äì it's got the same soulful vibe as some classic jazz records.

movies.overview: Two South Africans set out to discover what happened to their unlikely musical hero, the mysterious 1970s rock 'n' roller, Rodriguez.

results.name: Stop Making Sense
results.summary: Jonathan Demme's concert film isn't just a performance; it's a carefully choreographed explosion of art-school cool, culminating in David Byrne's iconic giant suit. The way the stage slowly builds throughout the show, revealing more musicians and set pieces, is pure cinematic genius.

personalization.forUser: You'll love this! It's pure joy, like a live jazz set but with art-school weirdness‚Äîthink the energy of your favorite experimental music, but visually stunning.

movies.overview: A concert film documenting Talking Heads at the height of their popularity, on tour for their 1983 album "Speaking in Tongues." The band takes the stage one by one and is joined by a cadre of guest musicians for a career-spanning and cinematic performance that features creative choreography and visuals.

results.name: The Last Waltz
results.summary: Robbie Robertson's guitar practically weeps in "The Last Waltz," Scorsese's love letter to The Band's farewell concert. Beyond the hits, it's the palpable camaraderie (and simmering tension) between the musicians that makes this an all-timer ‚Äì especially when Neil Young takes the stage, sporting a frankly ridiculous amount of tape holding his harmonica in place.

personalization.forUser: You'll love this! It's Scorsese directing a documentary about The Band's farewell concert, and the jazz influence is HUGE, so it's right up your alley.

movies.overview: Martin Scorsese's documentary intertwines footage from The Band's incredible farewell tour with probing backstage interviews and featured performances by Eric Clapton, Bob Dylan, Joni Mitchell, Van Morrison, and other rock legends.

results.name: Buena Vista Social Club
results.summary: This isn't just a documentary; it's a time capsule transporting you to the heart of pre-revolution Cuban music. Ry Cooder's discovery of these forgotten legends, like Ibrahim Ferrer, whose voice is unbelievably smooth, makes for a profoundly moving and joyous experience.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for "world" music, especially its vibrant rhythms and cultural storytelling, you'll adore this. The improvisational spirit will remind you of "jazz", but with a Cuban twist!

movies.overview: In this fascinating Oscar-nominated documentary, American guitarist Ry Cooder brings together a group of legendary Cuban folk musicians (some in their 90s) to record a Grammy-winning CD in their native city of Havana. The result is a spectacular compilation of concert footage from the group's gigs in Amsterdam and New York City's famed Carnegie Hall, with director Wim Wenders capturing not only the music -- but also the musicians' life stories.

results.name: Wattstax
results.summary: Wattstax isn't just a concert film; it's a time capsule of Black culture in 1972 Los Angeles, punctuated by searing social commentary from Richard Pryor. The Staple Singers' performance alone is worth the price of admission, radiating pure joy and spiritual power.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for jazz and experimental music, you'll find the raw energy of Wattstax irresistible‚Äîit's like a live, sprawling jazz improvisation session that captures a specific moment in time. But be warned: if you're not in the mood for a deep dive into a specific cultural moment, this one might feel a bit long.

movies.overview: A documentary film about the Afro-American Woodstock concert held in Los Angeles seven years after the Watts riots. Director Mel Stuart mixes footage from the concert with footage of the living conditions in the current-day Watts neighborhood.

results.name: Gimme Shelter
results.summary: What starts as a chronicle of the Rolling Stones' 1969 tour spirals into something darker, capturing the unraveling of the Altamont Free Concert and the tragic death of Meredith Hunter. The Maysles brothers' unflinching gaze makes this less a concert film and more a haunting document of a generation's disillusionment, with Mick Jagger's horrified reaction to the violence caught on camera a truly chilling moment.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for experimental music, you'll appreciate how this documentary captures the raw, chaotic energy of the Rolling Stones' Altamont concert, a far cry from polished studio recordings. But be warned, it's a pretty intense look at a dark moment in music history.

movies.overview: A detailed chronicle of the famous 1969 tour of the United States by the British rock band The Rolling Stones, which culminated with the disastrous and tragic concert held on December 6 at the Altamont Speedway Free Festival, an event of historical significance, as it marked the end of an era: the generation of peace and love suddenly became the generation of disillusionment.

results.name: 20 Feet from Stardom
results.summary: Darlene Love's voice will blow you away ‚Äì it's criminal she wasn't a household name sooner, and this documentary finally gives backup singers their due. The stories of these incredible talents, often just a few feet from superstardom but never quite reaching it, are both inspiring and heartbreaking.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for jazz and experimental music, you'll appreciate the spotlight on the often-unsung backup singers who contribute so much soul to iconic tracks ‚Äî it's a real celebration of musical talent beyond the headliners.

movies.overview: Backup singers live in a world that lies just beyond the spotlight. Their voices bring harmony to the biggest bands in popular music, but we've had no idea who these singers are or what lives they lead, until now.

results.name: Hype!
results.summary: If you want to *feel* the seismic shift that hip-hop's early years represented, this is it. The film makes you feel like you are at Woodstock for Hip Hop, and it's incredible how much footage they got of the early house parties.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for "experimental" music, you'll appreciate the raw energy and innovative soundscapes that define the Hyperdub sound. But be warned: it's a far cry from the smooth sounds of jazz you enjoy, so brace yourself for something intense.

movies.overview: This documentary examines the Seattle scene as it became the focus of a merging of punk rock, heavy metal, and innovation. Building from the grass roots, self-promoted and self-recorded until break-out success of bands like Nirvana brought the record industry to the Pacific Northwest, a phenomenon was born.

results.name: Dig!
results.summary: You'll feel like you're right there in the chaotic, ego-fueled rivalry between The Brian Jonestown Massacre and The Dandy Warhols. Anton Newcombe's self-destructive genius is mesmerizing, and the way the film captures the music scene's raw energy is incredible; you won't believe how much drama can unfold over record deals and tambourine solos.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for experimental music, you'll find the contrasting approaches of The Brian Jonestown Massacre and The Dandy Warhols fascinating, and the behind-the-scenes drama is captivating.

movies.overview: A documentary on the once promising American rock bands The Brian Jonestown Massacre and The Dandy Warhols. The friendship between respective founders, Anton Newcombe and Courtney Taylor, escalated into bitter rivalry as the Dandy Warhols garnered major international success while the Brian Jonestown Massacre imploded in a haze of drugs.

turns.query: documentaries specifically about jazz musicians

results.name: Bird
results.summary: Clint Eastwood's biopic of Charlie Parker is a flawed but fascinating look at a troubled genius; Forest Whitaker absolutely *becomes* Bird, capturing the raw emotion and self-destructive tendencies that fueled his revolutionary music.

personalization.forUser: You're a jazz fan, and this deep dive into Charlie Parker's revolutionary bebop will be right up your alley. Expect a raw and honest look at his genius and struggles.

movies.overview: Saxophone player Charlie ‚ÄòBird‚Äô Parker comes to New York in 1940 and is quickly noticed for his remarkable way of playing. He becomes a drug addict but his loving wife Chan tries to help him.

results.name: Miles Davis: Birth of the Cool
results.summary: This documentary pulls no punches in exploring the complexities of Miles Davis, both the musical innovator and the deeply flawed human being; the film uses Davis' own voice, culled from interviews and writings, to narrate his turbulent life and groundbreaking work, making it feel incredibly intimate.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for jazz and experimental music, you'll appreciate the film's exploration of Miles Davis' groundbreaking modal jazz era. The cool, understated vibe will definitely resonate.

movies.overview: An immersive look at the eventful life and brilliant artistic career of visionary American jazz trumpeter Miles Davis (1926-1991).

results.name: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary
results.summary: Prepare to be transported by this reverential and immersive portrait of John Coltrane; rare archival footage and recordings, combined with insightful interviews (including Denzel Washington reading Coltrane's own words), create a truly spiritual experience.

personalization.forUser: You'll definitely connect with this one, Jordan, as it delves into the spiritual side of John Coltrane's music, a theme that often surfaces in your favorite world music.

movies.overview: An account of the life of the brilliant jazz musician John Coltrane (1926-67), a gifted saxophonist, an extraordinarily talented thinker whose original, avant-garde work has impacted and influenced people all over the world. A story about music's ability to entertain, inspire and transform.

results.name: Lady Day: The Many Faces of Billie Holiday
results.summary: This documentary bravely explores the complex layers of Billie Holiday's life, going beyond the tragic headlines to reveal the strength and resilience that fueled her artistry; the use of previously unheard recordings of Holiday speaking about her life adds a chilling intimacy.

personalization.forUser: This one's a must-see for you; the raw emotion and vulnerability in Billie Holiday's voice will hit you hard, just like the Ethiopian jazz singers you admire.

movies.overview: Lady Day: The Many Faces of Billie Holiday integrates film and video performances, recordings, words from her controversial autobiography (read by actress Ruby Dee) and interviews with artists who played with her (pianist Mal Waldron, trumpeter Buck Clayton and Harry "Sweets" Edison), Milt Gabler (owner of Commodore and a producer at Decca), author Albert Murray and vocalists Carmen McRae and Annie Ross.

results.name: Keep On Keepin' On
results.summary: This heartwarming documentary follows the unlikely friendship between legendary jazz trumpeter Clark Terry and his blind prot√©g√©, Justin Kauflin; it's a masterclass in mentorship and the power of music to transcend limitations, and you'll be reaching for your Kleenex more than once.

personalization.forUser: This documentary about the friendship between Clark Terry and Justin Kauflin might feel a bit sentimental, but its focus on mentorship and musical legacy will speak to your appreciation for jazz.

movies.overview: Eighty-nine year old trumpeting legend Clark Terry has mentored jazz wonders like Miles Davis and Quincy Jones, but Terry‚Äôs most unlikely friendship is with Justin Kauflin, a 23-year-old blind piano player with uncanny talent, but debilitating nerves. As Justin prepares for the most pivotal moment in his budding career, Terry‚Äôs ailing health threatens to end his own.

results.name: Thelonious Monk: Straight, No Chaser
results.summary: This film offers a rare glimpse into the enigmatic world of Thelonious Monk, capturing his eccentric personality and unparalleled genius; the footage of Monk clowning around on the tour bus is priceless, revealing a playful side rarely seen on stage.

personalization.forUser: You'll appreciate this film's quirky and unconventional approach to portraying Thelonious Monk, a true original in jazz. It's as offbeat and brilliant as his music.

movies.overview: A documentary film about the life of pianist and jazz great Thelonious Monk. Features live performances by Monk and his band, and interviews with friends and family about the offbeat genius.

results.name: Sun Ra: A Joyful Noise
results.summary: Prepare for a wild ride through the cosmos with Sun Ra, the avant-garde jazz visionary who claimed to be from Saturn; this documentary is as eccentric and mind-bending as Ra himself, and it's impossible not to be captivated by his bizarre brilliance.

personalization.forUser: You'll either love or hate this one, Jordan; Sun Ra's cosmic philosophy and avant-garde jazz are definitely out there. But since you dig experimental music, you might find it fascinating.

movies.overview: Robert Mugge filmed jazz great Sun Ra on location in Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Washington, D.C. between 1978 and 1980. The resulting 60-minute film includes multiple public and private performances, poetry readings, a band rehearsal, interviews, and extensive improvisations. Transferred to HD from the original 16mm film and lovingly restored for the best possible viewing experience.

results.name: Benny Goodman: Adventures in the Kingdom of Swing
results.summary: While a bit dated, this documentary offers a fascinating glimpse into the life and career of Benny Goodman, the 'King of Swing'; it's particularly interesting for its historical context, showcasing the groundbreaking impact of Goodman's integrated band during a time of racial segregation, even if the presentation feels a bit old-fashioned.

personalization.forUser: While Goodman's swing era is a bit more mainstream than your usual jazz picks, this classic documentary provides valuable insight into the 'King of Swing' and his impact on American music.

movies.overview: This biography of musical legend Benny Goodman contains testimonials from various contemporaries and scholars, and offers several clips of the man in performance. Nearly two-dozen songs can be heard including "California, Here I Come," "A Fine Romance," "Why Don't You Do Right," "I've Got a Heart Full of Music," and "Bugle Cal Rag."

turns.query: best anime series to watch

results.name: Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba the Movie: Mugen Train
results.summary: The animation in this movie is breathtaking, especially the fight sequences against Enmu‚Äîthe blend of 2D and 3D is seamless and adds a new level of dynamism. It's an emotional rollercoaster; be prepared to cry, particularly during Rengoku's final stand.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for 'anime', especially the visually stunning works, you'll be hooked by the breathtaking animation and intense fight choreography in this one. It's like a supercharged, emotional rollercoaster that you won't want to miss.

movies.overview: Tanjiro Kamado, joined with Inosuke Hashibira, a boy raised by boars who wears a boar's head, and Zenitsu Agatsuma, a scared boy who reveals his true power when he sleeps, boards the Infinity Train on a new mission with the Fire Hashira, Kyojuro Rengoku, to defeat a demon who has been tormenting the people and killing the demon slayers who oppose it!

results.name: Spirited Away
results.summary: Hayao Miyazaki at his absolute peak ‚Äî the bathhouse setting is endlessly inventive, but it's the surprisingly tender relationship between Chihiro and Haku that makes it truly special. Pay close attention to the 'river spirit' scene; it's a masterclass in visual storytelling and environmental commentary.

personalization.forUser: Since you love Studio Ghibli, you'll adore this‚Äî the bathhouse setting is so imaginative, and the themes of identity and courage really resonate.

movies.overview: A young girl, Chihiro, becomes trapped in a strange new world of spirits. When her parents undergo a mysterious transformation, she must call upon the courage she never knew she had to free her family.

results.name: Your Name.
results.summary: Makoto Shinkai's visuals are breathtaking, and the way the film weaves together natural disasters, body-switching, and teenage romance is surprisingly resonant. The climax, where the protagonist has to choose between saving a city and saving the girl he loves, hits hard.

personalization.forUser: Recommended for Matt

movies.overview: High schoolers Mitsuha and Taki are complete strangers living separate lives. But one night, they suddenly switch places. Mitsuha wakes up in Taki‚Äôs body, and he in hers. This bizarre occurrence continues to happen randomly, and the two must adjust their lives around each other.

results.name: Princess Mononoke
results.summary: Forget Disney's sanitized takes on nature; Mononoke is a full-throated roar about humanity's greed and nature's fury. The forest spirit's transformation is genuinely terrifying, a far cry from Bambi, and proof that Miyazaki wasn't afraid to get dark.

personalization.forUser: Matt, you'll adore this! It‚Äôs peak "studio ghibli" magic, with a sweeping story and stunning visuals that'll grab you from the start.

movies.overview: Ashitaka, a prince of the disappearing Emishi people, is cursed by a demonized boar god and must journey to the west to find a cure. Along the way, he encounters San, a young human woman fighting to protect the forest, and Lady Eboshi, who is trying to destroy it. Ashitaka must find a way to bring balance to this conflict.

results.name: Akira
results.summary: The motorcycle chase sequences alone are worth the price of admission ‚Äì Katsuhiro Otomo's cyberpunk masterpiece still looks incredible, and the sound design is unbelievably immersive, especially the dissonant synth score. It's a wild ride that doesn't always make perfect sense, but it absolutely sticks with you.

personalization.forUser: Matt, this is quintessential anime, and since you're into the genre, you'll love it. The animation style is a little different from your usual Studio Ghibli, but trust me, the cyberpunk world and intense story will suck you in.

movies.overview: A secret military project endangers Neo-Tokyo when it turns a biker gang member into a rampaging psychic psychopath that only two teenagers and a group of psychics can stop.

results.name: Weathering with You
results.summary: Makoto Shinkai's visuals are always stunning, but the way the rain *feels* in this movie is something else entirely ‚Äì almost tactile. The ending is pretty divisive (it's not afraid to make bold choices), but the soundtrack alone is worth the price of admission.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for "studio ghibli", you'll definitely appreciate the stunning visuals and coming-of-age story here, though the pacing is a bit faster and the stakes higher than most of Miyazaki's work.

movies.overview: The summer of his high school freshman year, Hodaka runs away from his remote island home to Tokyo, and quickly finds himself pushed to his financial and personal limits. The weather is unusually gloomy and rainy every day, as if taking its cue from his life. After many days of solitude, he finally finds work as a freelance writer for a mysterious occult magazine. Then, one day, Hodaka meets Hina on a busy street corner. This bright and strong-willed girl possesses a strange and wonderful ability: the power to stop the rain and clear the sky.

results.name: The Girl Who Leapt Through Time
results.summary: This movie isn't just a fun time-travel romp; it's a surprisingly poignant coming-of-age story anchored by a killer soundtrack (seriously, the theme song will be stuck in your head for days). The scene where Makoto uses her powers to avoid awkward romantic confessions is both hilarious and heartbreaking, perfectly capturing the messy emotions of adolescence.

personalization.forUser: Matt, you'll love this! It's got that beautiful, melancholic feel that often comes with studio ghibli films, but with a unique time-bending twist that'll keep you hooked.

movies.overview: When 17-year-old Makoto Konno gains the ability to 'leap' backwards through time, she immediately sets about improving her grades and preventing personal mishaps. However, she soon realises that changing the past isn't as simple as it seems, and eventually, will have to rely on her new powers to shape the future of herself and her friends.

results.name: A Silent Voice
results.summary: Prepare to be emotionally wrecked, but in the best way possible. The way the film portrays the lingering effects of childhood bullying, especially through its stunning visuals and use of sound (or lack thereof), is just incredible.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for "anime" and especially the emotional depth of "studio ghibli" films, you'll find this movie deeply moving; the story tackles tough themes with incredible sensitivity. The animation during the bridge scene is gorgeous; you won't forget it.

movies.overview: Shouya Ishida starts bullying the new girl in class, Shouko Nishimiya, because she is deaf. But as the teasing continues, the rest of the class starts to turn on Shouya for his lack of compassion. When they leave elementary school, Shouko and Shouya do not speak to each other again... until an older, wiser Shouya, tormented by his past behaviour, decides he must see Shouko once more. He wants to atone for his sins, but is it already too late...?

results.name: Howl's Moving Castle
results.summary: This movie is pure visual poetry ‚Äì the titular castle itself is a steampunk fever dream. The quiet moments between Howl and Sophie are unexpectedly moving, especially when you realize Howl's fear stems from protecting the beauty he finds in the world.

personalization.forUser: Matt, since you're into "studio ghibli", you'll love the whimsy and heart in this one‚Äîplus, the visuals are stunning, especially Howl's transformations.

movies.overview: Sophie, a young milliner, is turned into an elderly woman by a witch who enters her shop and curses her. She encounters a wizard named Howl and gets caught up in his resistance to fighting for the king.

results.name: Neon Genesis Evangelion: The End of Evangelion
results.summary: Forget giant robots ‚Äî this is a psychological horror movie masquerading as a mecha anime, culminating in one of the most disturbing and unforgettable endings in animation history. The infamous scene where Shinji chokes Asuka is a masterclass in uncomfortable, raw emotion that will leave you reeling.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for anime and the visually stunning storytelling of Studio Ghibli films, this one's a must-watch; it's a darker, more psychologically complex take on giant robots, but the artistry will blow you away.

movies.overview: SEELE orders an all-out attack on NERV, aiming to destroy the Evas before Gendo can advance his own plans for the Human Instrumentality Project. Shinji is pushed to the limits of his sanity as he is forced to decide the fate of humanity.

turns.query: anime similar to Miyazaki with nature themes and gentle pacing

results.name: Wolf Children
results.summary: Okay, prepare to cry. Mamoru Hosoda's *Wolf Children* is like a Miyazaki film distilled to its purest emotional core, following a young woman raising her half-wolf children in the countryside after their father's tragic death ‚Äî the scene where Yuki transitions from wanting to be a wolf to wanting to be a 'normal' girl is absolutely heartbreaking.

personalization.forUser: Since you're into anime and Studio Ghibli, you'll love this one ‚Äì it has that same gentle heart and stunning nature animation. The story is beautiful and a bit of a tearjerker, but in a good way.

movies.overview: After her werewolf lover unexpectedly dies in an accident, a woman must find a way to raise the son and daughter that she had with him. However, their inheritance of their father's traits prove to be a challenge for her.

results.name: Summer Wars
results.summary: This one's a wild ride ‚Äì imagine a Miyazaki film blended with a techno-thriller, where a math genius has to save the world from a rogue AI using his coding skills. The traditional Japanese family dynamic clashing with the virtual world of OZ creates a visual feast, and the climactic battle is surprisingly emotional.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for Studio Ghibli, you'll appreciate the family dynamics and heartwarming story, but be warned, the internet battles are way more intense than anything in Miyazaki's films.

movies.overview: Teenage math whiz Kenji Koiso agrees to take a summer job at the Nagano hometown of his crush, Natsuki. When he arrives, he finds that her family have reunited to celebrate the 90th birthday of their matriarch. His job: pretend to be Natsuki's fianc√©. Meanwhile, his attempt to solve a mathematical equation causes a parallel world's collision with Earth.

results.name: Patema Inverted
results.summary: Imagine a world where gravity is relative, and falling upwards is a very real danger. This film has some truly breathtaking visuals as Patema and Age explore their connected worlds, but the plot gets a little convoluted in the second half, unfortunately.

personalization.forUser: Since you're a fan of anime and Studio Ghibli, you'll appreciate the imaginative world-building in this one, but the pacing is a bit faster and the plot more twisty than Miyazaki's gentler narratives, so go in prepared for a different vibe.

movies.overview: A young girl, from a civilization that resides in deep underground tunnels, finds herself trapped in an inverted world and teams up with a resident to escape and return home.

results.name: Children Who Chase Lost Voices
results.summary: Makoto Shinkai's early work wears its Miyazaki influence on its sleeve, but it's still gorgeous and emotionally resonant. The film's depiction of the underworld, Agartha, is surprisingly melancholic and haunting, a far cry from the typical fantasy setting.

personalization.forUser: Since you're a fan of Studio Ghibli, the visuals here will definitely grab you, but be warned: the story gets a bit more complex and emotionally heavy than your typical Miyazaki flick.

movies.overview: The film centers on Asuna, a young girl who spends her solitary days listening to the mysterious music emanating from the crystal radio she received from her late father as a memento. One day while walking home she is attacked by a fearsome monster and saved by a mysterious boy named Shun. However, Shun disappears and Asuna embarks on a journey of adventure to the land of Agartha with her teacher Mr. Morisaki to meet a Shun again. Through her journey she comes to know the cruelty and beauty of the world, as well as loss.

results.name: The Girl Who Leapt Through Time
results.summary: This isn't just a time travel story; it's a poignant exploration of youth and responsibility, wrapped in a deceptively simple package. The watercolor-esque backgrounds give it a hazy, nostalgic feel that perfectly complements Makoto's journey of self-discovery, especially during the iconic bicycle scene against the sunset.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for anime and Studio Ghibli, this one's a must-watch. The animation style feels familiar, but the time-travel twist keeps things fresh and engaging, offering a similar sense of wonder.

movies.overview: When 17-year-old Makoto Konno gains the ability to 'leap' backwards through time, she immediately sets about improving her grades and preventing personal mishaps. However, she soon realises that changing the past isn't as simple as it seems, and eventually, will have to rely on her new powers to shape the future of herself and her friends.

results.name: A Letter to Momo
results.summary: This is a heartfelt coming-of-age story with yokai! The hand-drawn animation is gorgeous, especially the vibrant depictions of rural Japan, and the mischievous yokai add a touch of whimsy without sacrificing the emotional core of Momo's grief.

personalization.forUser: Given your love for Studio Ghibli, you'll adore this. The yokai designs are whimsical, and the story shares that same gentle heart you appreciate in Miyazaki's films.

movies.overview: A shy 11-year-old's life takes a strange turn when she discovers three hungry goblins living in the attic of her new house. She misses her old life. She misses her father so very much. Until she makes some new ghoulish friends.

results.name: Penguin Highway
results.summary: Don't let the penguins fool you, this is a coming-of-age story with a sci-fi twist that's way more profound than it lets on. The animation style is gorgeous and the mystery surrounding the penguins is genuinely captivating ‚Äì plus, the ending is a total tearjerker, in the best way.

personalization.forUser: Since you love anime and Studio Ghibli movies, you'll adore this one ‚Äî the sense of childlike wonder and the beautiful, slightly surreal nature themes are right up your alley.

movies.overview: A fourth-grader investigates the mysterious reason behind the sudden appearance of penguins in his village, which is somehow related to a power from a young woman working at a dental clinic.

results.name: Josee, the Tiger and the Fish
results.summary: Okay, so it's not Miyazaki, but if you want a tender, character-driven story with gorgeous seaside animation, give this a shot. The way they render the blues of the ocean is breathtaking, and the central romance, while a bit melodramatic, really got to me.

personalization.forUser: Since you're into anime and Studio Ghibli, this'll be right up your alley; it's a super-sweet, character-focused story with a similar gentle vibe, even if the animation style is a bit different.

movies.overview: With dreams of diving abroad, Tsuneo gets a job assisting Josee, an artist whose imagination takes her far beyond her wheelchair. But when the tide turns against them, they push each other to places they never thought possible, and inspire a love fit for a storybook.

results.name: Liz and the Blue Bird
results.summary: Prepare to be swept away by its quiet intensity; the film's focus on sound design is incredible, using layered musical motifs to convey unspoken emotions between two young musicians on the cusp of graduation. It's less about grand adventure and more about the bittersweet ache of growing apart, told with breathtaking visual restraint.

personalization.forUser: Since you are a fan of anime and Studio Ghibli, you'll appreciate the delicate character animation and emotional depth, but be warned, the pacing is much slower and more focused on subtle interactions than Miyazaki's grand adventures.

movies.overview: In their last year of high school, two girls in the brass band club perform a song inspired by a fairy tale that parallels their friendship.

results.name: Mary and the Witch's Flower
results.summary: While it has Studio Ghibli vibes on the surface, this one falls short of Miyazaki's magic; the plot feels rushed, and the animation, while pretty, lacks the depth of character found in classics like *Spirited Away* ‚Äî the glowing blue fly-by-night flower is a cool visual, though.

personalization.forUser: Since you're into Studio Ghibli, you'll find familiar vibes here with its whimsical animation and focus on a young protagonist discovering a magical world. That said, the pacing is a bit faster than Miyazaki's films, so be prepared for a slightly different tempo.

movies.overview: Mary Smith, a young girl who lives with her great-aunt in the countryside, follows a mysterious cat into the nearby forest where she finds a strange flower and an old broom, none of which is as ordinary as it seems.

turns.query: mind-bending sci-fi movies like Arrival or Interstellar

results.name: Contact
results.summary: Jodie Foster carries this movie, playing a scientist obsessed with finding extraterrestrial life. The scene where she *thinks* she makes contact is both exhilarating and terrifying, and it'll leave you wondering what's real.

personalization.forUser: You're gonna dig this, Alex. It nails the slow-burn tension and philosophical questions that you loved in *Arrival*, but with a more grounded, less overtly sci-fi feel.

movies.overview: A radio astronomer receives the first extraterrestrial radio signal ever picked up on Earth. As the world powers scramble to decipher the message and decide upon a course of action, she must make some difficult decisions between her beliefs, the truth, and reality.

results.name: Annihilation
results.summary: Visually stunning and deeply unsettling, Annihilation burrows into your subconscious with its surreal imagery and themes of self-destruction. The shimmering, mutated flora and fauna are gorgeous, but the film's exploration of grief and identity is what truly lingers.

personalization.forUser: Okay, you'll love this. It's got that same sense of dread and wonder as Arrival, but with a heavy dose of cosmic horror‚Äîminus the gore, so you're safe from the horror you despise. Think Stalker meets your beloved sci-fi.

movies.overview: A biologist signs up for a dangerous, secret expedition into a mysterious zone where the laws of nature don't apply.

results.name: Primer
results.summary: Don't even try to understand the plot on the first watch ‚Äî just surrender to the feeling of escalating dread as two engineers stumble upon time travel in their garage. The fact that it was made for $7,000 adds to the mind-bending quality, making it a truly unique and unsettling experience.

personalization.forUser: Time travel with zero Hollywood gloss ‚Äì this one's all about the intricate plotting and mind-bending paradoxes, like a logic puzzle Radiohead might write. It's low-budget and dense, so if you need constant action, skip this, but if you loved the slow-burn reveals of Arrival, you'll be hooked.

movies.overview: A group of fledgling inventors discover a complex method to manipulate reality. At first, they successfully game the stock market with it, but the consequences of the invention start to catch up with them.

results.name: Predestination
results.summary: Sarah Snook *crushes* it in this time-bending thriller where identity is fluid and nothing is as it seems; the twist involving the character's origin is genuinely shocking, and the film earns its mind-blowing reputation.

personalization.forUser: Okay, if you dug the time-bending in Arrival, prepare for this one to tie your brain in knots ‚Äì think Philip K. Dick meets a really twisted episode of Twilight Zone. It's light on huge sci-fi visuals, Alex, so you won't get the Interstellar-scale spectacle, but the story's the thing here, and it's a wild ride.

movies.overview: Predestination chronicles the life of a Temporal Agent sent on an intricate series of time-travel journeys designed to prevent future killers from committing their crimes. Now, on his final assignment, the Agent must stop the one criminal that has eluded him throughout time and prevent a devastating attack in which thousands of lives will be lost.

results.name: Coherence
results.summary: Forget big explosions; "Coherence" messes with your head in the best way possible. A dinner party gone sideways thanks to a passing comet leads to some seriously unsettling realities, and the low-budget feel only adds to the claustrophobia.

personalization.forUser: You'll absolutely love this mind-bender; it hits that same cerebral sweet spot as Arrival but with a Lynchian twist that'll remind you of the surreal imagery in your favorite David Fincher films. Be warned: it demands patience and rewards multiple viewings, so if you're not in the mood for something that unfolds slowly, maybe skip it.

movies.overview: Four couples gather for dinner the night a mysterious and powerful comet passes overhead.

results.name: Source Code
results.summary: Jake Gyllenhaal relives the same few minutes of a train bombing to find the bomber, but the real trip is the film's exploration of consciousness and what it means to truly *connect* with someone. The ending is surprisingly hopeful, considering the premise involves repeated deaths and explosions ‚Äì it sticks with you.

personalization.forUser: You'll love the heady, philosophical questions it raises, like in Arrival, but be warned: it's far more dialogue-heavy and less visually driven, so dial down your Interstellar expectations.

movies.overview: When decorated soldier Captain Colter Stevens wakes up in the body of an unknown man, he discovers he's part of a mission to find the bomber of a Chicago commuter train.

results.name: Moon
results.summary: Claustrophobic and unsettling, Duncan Jones' *Moon* is a masterclass in minimalist sci-fi ‚Äî Sam Rockwell gives a career-defining performance as a lone lunar miner slowly losing his grip, and the reveal about the true nature of his existence is genuinely haunting.

personalization.forUser: Oh, you'll be hooked from the opening scene ‚Äî it's got that same thoughtful, slow-burn feel as Arrival, but with a haunting score that would make Radiohead proud. Plus, the isolation and existential dread? Right up your alley.

movies.overview: With only three weeks left in his three-year contract, Sam Bell is eager to return to Earth. Stationed alone at a Moon-based facility with his computer assistant GERTY, an unexpected accident sets off a series of unsettling events that shake his isolation.

results.name: Donnie Darko
results.summary: This movie is a trip ‚Äî Jake Gyllenhaal delivers a career-defining performance as a troubled teen plagued by visions of a sinister rabbit. The soundtrack alone, especially the use of Tears for Fears' "Mad World," elevates it from sci-fi to something truly haunting and unforgettable.

personalization.forUser: If you're chasing that Interstellar vibe of questioning reality, you'll love this. It's got that same thread of time bending and teenage angst, but trades the cosmic scale for a more personal, suburban nightmare.

movies.overview: After narrowly escaping a bizarre accident, a troubled teenager is plagued by visions of a large bunny rabbit that manipulates him to commit a series of crimes.

results.name: Triangle
results.summary: Melissa George relives the same cruise ship massacre over and over, and the time-loop logic is airtight ‚Äî it's a brutal, underrated thriller with a gut-punch ending that'll leave you reeling, but the real horror is the crushing weight of predestination.

personalization.forUser: Okay, this is a trip. It's got that same time-loop dread as Primer, but dialed up with a slasher-movie twist. It‚Äôs definitely more intense than Arrival, but if you dug the philosophical puzzles, you'll be hooked.

movies.overview: When Jess sets sail on a yacht with a group of friends, she cannot shake the feeling that there is something wrong.

results.name: The Fountain
results.summary: Darren Aronofsky's time-hopping love story is either a masterpiece or a mess, but it's NEVER boring; Hugh Jackman plays different versions of the same man across centuries, all connected by a search for immortality and love that's visually stunning and emotionally raw. The film's score, by Clint Mansell, is absolutely haunting and elevates the whole experience.

personalization.forUser: You'll love this if you're chasing that same emotional, philosophical depth you found in *Arrival*‚Äîit's visually stunning, with a score that echoes some of the quieter moments of Radiohead, but be warned, it's a much more metaphorical and emotionally intense ride.

movies.overview: Spanning over one thousand years, and three parallel stories, The Fountain is a story of love, death, spirituality, and the fragility of our existence in this world.

flags: üö© "right up your alley" with empty profile

turns.query: best jazz albums of all time

results.name: Kind of Blue
results.summary: It's the album that turned countless people (including me!) onto jazz. The modal harmonies create this late-night, smoky atmosphere, and the fact that it was mostly improvised in the studio adds to its legendary status.

personalization.forUser: You'll love this album, Jordan. It's like the jazz equivalent of a great documentary ‚Äì deeply insightful and timeless, just like your favorite documentaries.

results.name: A Love Supreme
results.summary: This isn't just an album; it's a spiritual journey put to music. The insistent, almost chant-like repetition of the title phrase in the final movement, 'Psalm,' is absolutely mesmerizing and unlike anything else Coltrane ever recorded. It's less a jazz album and more a prayer.

personalization.forUser: Given your soft spot for experimental music, you'll love the spiritual and improvisational nature of this album. It's a jazz masterpiece that echoes the same boundary-pushing spirit you appreciate in artists from the world music scene.

results.name: The Black Saint and the Sinner Lady
results.summary: Charles Mingus's masterpiece is a sprawling, swirling psychodrama in sound. It's a deeply personal work‚ÄîMingus actually included a brief liner note analyzing his own personality using psychiatric terms‚Äîand it absolutely explodes with passion and innovation.

personalization.forUser: You'll dig this: it's basically a sprawling, avant-garde tone poem. Think of the most out-there moments from your experimental music dives, but with a big band.

results.name: Saxophone Colossus
results.summary: Sonny Rollins' "Saxophone Colossus" isn't just an album, it's a statement. "St. Thomas" alone, with its calypso rhythm, will have you hooked, but it's Rollins' raw, almost conversational tone on the sax that makes this a must-listen; you feel like he's telling you a story.

personalization.forUser: You'll love Sonny Rollins's "Saxophone Colossus" because it's a masterclass in improvisation, much like the experimental music you enjoy. The track "St. Thomas" has a calypso feel that will remind you of some world music influences, too.

results.name: Ella and Louis
results.summary: You've heard "Dream a Little Dream of Me," but have you *listened*? Ella's playful scatting dances around Louis' gravelly vocals like they're sharing an inside joke, and that's the magic of this album: pure, unadulterated joy, even down to the way Louis' trumpet mirrors her vocal runs.

personalization.forUser: Jordan, you'll love this! It's a fantastic introduction to jazz, especially if you're coming from 'world' music; Ella's vocal improvisations have a similar playful energy.

results.name: Giant Steps
results.summary: John Coltrane's "Giant Steps" is a wild ride of harmonic innovation ‚Äì pure exhilaration or dizzying chaos, depending on your ear. The title track's relentless chord changes are legendary, a gauntlet thrown down to every improviser since.

personalization.forUser: You'll either love or hate this one, Jordan. It's a masterclass in complex harmony, but if you're looking for something more like the world music you dig, this might feel a little too academic.

results.name: Mingus Ah Um
results.summary: Charles Mingus's masterpiece is a vibrant tapestry of sound, swinging from joyous celebration to mournful reflection‚Äîit's the sound of pure, unadulterated feeling. The extended version of "Goodbye Pork Pie Hat," a tribute to Lester Young, is particularly heart-wrenching and showcases Mingus's incredible ability to evoke emotion through music.

personalization.forUser: You'll love this album because it‚Äôs got that experimental edge you dig, but it's also rooted in the blues like some of your favorite world music‚Äîthink of it as a sonic journey with a touch of Charles Mingus's signature rebellious spirit.

results.name: Time Out
results.summary: Dave Brubeck's *Time Out* isn't just iconic; it's a masterclass in making odd time signatures sound utterly natural and groovy. The way "Take Five" became a mainstream hit despite being in 5/4 time is a testament to its sheer brilliance and enduring appeal -- it's a jazz gateway drug for a reason.

personalization.forUser: Since you're into experimental music, check out Dave Brubeck's 'Time Out' ‚Äì the unusual time signatures will grab your attention, especially if you dig that off-kilter Radiohead vibe.

results.name: Lady in Satin
results.summary: Billie Holiday's voice is fragile and heartbreaking, but the lush, almost saccharine orchestral arrangements create a stunning contrast. The way she lingers on the word "glad" in "You're My Thrill" just rips your heart out ‚Äî it's a masterpiece of vulnerability.

personalization.forUser: You'll love Billie Holiday's 'Lady in Satin.' The lush arrangements and her heartbreaking vocals are a world away from your usual experimental stuff, but the emotional depth is undeniable, like a Peruvian folk song that just guts you.

results.name: Getz/Gilberto
